Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Believe our layer of concern is where the rain crusts from early July are deteriorating into melt forms and well-defined polycrystals. The ECTP was most likely a false positive. We were not able to replicate the result.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit by Irene and Oli. Bottom (12cm-0cm) variable with loose pockets around scree. Long term concern layer is IFrc/FC sandwich.
Week 4 of weekly pit tracking. Pit by Alicia and Kane

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Slope representative of a loaded slope adjacent
snow stripped from ridge

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug by Irene Henninger + Brandon Rollin. Explosives control 48 hours earlier yielded few Size 1-2 on similar slopes failing above IFrc where CT/ECT result occurred, but in areas with more HST loaded on top. No reactivity since. IFrc layers variable and inconsistent throughout pit. Entire snowpack beneath IFrc had water percolate through it during rain events.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Incoming NW front

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Cross loaded slope actually lee to the NW due to wrap around the basin
Test results happened below P RGwp on top of F FC that was not present throughout the pit. Dug by Oli and Mark

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area
Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Claggy/thin overcast. Greenhousing beginning to take effect on surface layer. Minimal skier traffic through the area. 190703 Rain event percolated through entire snowpack but is now dry. Surface is variable sastrugi, and all the crust layers in upper half are very irregular with no consistent, smooth interfaces between the layers. Largest concern is F RG just below surface with addition of new HST.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Gale SE easing during operations

Week 2 of weekly pit tracking. 40m East of Wx station. 5cm of new PP on top of a 5cm IFrc with a notable layer 9cm deep of Fc. Failure on this Fc layer 9cm down when isolated for tests but not propagating. This is my current layer of concern, with substantial loading this layer could be problematic. Pit by Aimee Prendergast
3 de julio, avalancha de placa profundidad, resultado de placa de viento sobrecargando la capa débil del 25 de mayo.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug in Back Bowl 1A. Snowpack has not yet reached threshold for concern. Test results were inconclusive, but the poor structure raises concerns for any load that may be added

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Week 1 of weekly pit tracking- 40m East of Wx Station. Surface RGwp of varying depths predominantly in start zones 10-30cm deep. Notable failures when isolated for tests but not conducive to entire slope failure at this time. Pit by Aimee Prendergrast, Joe Collinson, Irene Henninger

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Skier's left side, 20m below ridgeline. RGwp at surface present in most S and E start zones 10-30cm deep and dissipates by ~30m below. Notable failure beneath slab when isolated in tests but not conducive to entire slope failure. 2x ECT results. Pit dug by Irene Henninger and Grice Adams.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit dug in a Ski Area; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Depth isolated to upper slope. HS thins out as you descend. Pit dug by Brandon Rollin + Edward Norriss

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Located ~30m below ridgeline in upper Festival. Pit by Oli Cossette.

Pit_Observation.activities: Cracking; Recent activity on similar slopes
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Avalanches in past 2 days (D2-3, R2-3) on steep solar aspects (SW,S,SE) crossing HIT above cliffs section. Estimated slope angle at avalanche start zones greater than 45 degrees. Additional avalanches have released similarly in past 2 weeks as well. All avalanches have begun as hard slabs.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Objective: Monitor persistent weak layers. Site characteristics: BTL study plot. Open meadow with good sky view. Smooth ground cover.

ASc Loose and SS activity noted in top 10 cm, N aspects, steeper than 40*. E aspects at this elevation becoming unsupportive by 1300hrs. Isolated robust ice lenses up to 1cm thick and 10cm diameter associated with PWL at 200cm, with ice columns extending below. 200 layer chosen as layer of interest due more to attention-grabbing fracture character, than failure sensitivity. LyteProbe testing.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Top layer becoming cohesive on all aspects; should be easy for it to get legs on steep terrain. Buried SH at 160 more resistant than 6 days ago. Did not dig to ground.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: 7 minutes for the dig and 18 minute observation. Consolidated snowpack. We didn't measure total depth. AIARE2 class pit included Ben, Dominic, and Warner supervised by Jason Maurer. Temperature was approximate.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: HS 330cm, however only dug down 170cm. Dug in chute above Obellx near rock outcrop. Spx showed little evidence of recent warm temps except for surface MFcr. Unable to isolate below ice layer at 210cm for ECT.

ALP, skråladdad sluttning. Objectives: Drevsnömängd och reaktivitet. 24 feb Mrfc / Fc kändes med sonden ca 2 m ner.

Cross-slope PST 30/100 (end) at 170; nearby slope tests showing sensitivity to ski triggers in upper 15cm of wind-loaded new snow steeper than 35*; DTN's at basal layers leads me to focus on buried SH @ 170 as layer of concern. Ski pen 15cm. No densities observed from MF crust layers

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Recent activity on similar slopes
Collapsing, localized; Cracking; Instability rapidly rising; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope; Snowmobile tracks on slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Mild, rapid greenhousing started to take place shortly after this hand pit was performed. Ski cuts on steeper slopes produced pockets of storm slab avalanches (~12 inches deep) up to 20 feet wide, stubborn.
